awd_titl_txt: Support for U.S. Participation in the 2019 Canadian-American-Mexican Graduate Student Physics Conference July 24-27, 2019 in Sudbury, Canada
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to the American Physical Society (APS) for conference planning and student travel to participate in the joint Canadian, US, and Mexican physical societies' graduate student conference (CAM2019), to be held in Sudbury, Canada, July 24-27, 2019. This is an opportunity for physics graduate students to begin networking across borders. Throughout the conference, students will discuss current research in both formal and informal settings with international peers and professors. 

The CAM2097 workshop is designed for and by graduate students in all areas of physics. Plenary sessions will be given by well-known scientists in their sub-disciplines including Particle Physics, Astrophysics and Nuclear Physics, Condensed Matter Physics, Biophysics, Optics, Atomic Physics, Nanoscience, Computational Physics, and Materials Physics. The plenary sessions will be followed by contributed talks from the students. There will be two panel discussions on "International Physics Collaboration" and "Communication and Research" highlighting CAM2019's goal to foster student ability to transcend boundaries in physics. All students who attend will present their research in either a contributed talk or poster session. The organizers will continue a peer feedback program that was introduced at CAM2017 and was well received by the student speakers.  In addition to the traditional scientific program the CAM conference provides, CAM2019 attendees will be able to visit a major international physics facility (SNOLAB).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Canadian-American-Mexican Graduate Student Physics Conference (CAM) is a biennial conference sponsored by the Canadian Association of Physicists (CAP), the American Physical Society (APS), and the Sociedad Mexicana de Física (SMF). This conference has been organized by and for physics students, with support and guidance from senior staff of the respective professional societies, for nearly 20 years. The conference gives participants an opportunity to meet and collaborate with other physics graduate students from across North America. The conference includes plenary talks by senior scientists, panel sessions, poster and contributed presentations by the students, as well as social events. In addition to the organizers from Mexico, Canada, and the United States, a delegation from the Sociedad Cubana de Física (SCF) has also participated in the conference, including service on the international organizing committee, since 2017.  


CAM 2019 was held in Sudbury, Ontario, Canada from July 24-27, 2019. As CAM 2019 had the rare opportunity to bring attendees to a major international physics facility, SNOLAB, the conference was held at Laurentian University in Sudbury. CAP served as the host of CAM 2019, with partners at Laurentian University and SNOLAB assisting with local arrangements.

The conference was organized by and for the graduate students themselves with staff from the four physics societies providing the student organizers with mentorship and guidance. Student organizers were responsible for advertising the conference in their respective countries. In addition to the student and physics society organizers, representatives from Laurentian University and SNOLAB served on the local organizing committee. 

Unlike larger scientific conferences that graduate students attend, the CAM conference has a smaller, student-focused environment. Here the graduate students interact with their peers in both formal and informal settings and obtain immediate feedback on their presentations. Each graduate student presented their research in either a parallel or poster session. For many of the students, this was their first conference presenting their work to an international audience. Additionally, the students are not only able to hear talks from the invited, established scientists, but they also have the opportunity to interact and share their experiences with them. 


Plenary talks by senior scientists complimented the student presentations. In addition, three panel discussions were held on the following topics: “Careers and Planning,” “Funding in Science,” and “Publications.” Each session provided the opportunity for the students to interact with invited speakers and discuss topics relevant to student and early-career physicists. The students had ample opportunities to network with peers and scientists from other countries and subfields of physics. 


One of the highlights of the conference was the opportunity to tour the international physics facility SNOLAB as it was undergoing a maintenance and upgrade shutdown period. SNOLAB is an underground science laboratory specializing in neutrino and dark matter physics. Students were able to visit and learn about a modern large-scale experimental facility with collaborative international management and support. 

CAM 2019 promoted international collaboration, networking, and career development opportunities for physics graduate students from Canada, Cuba, Mexico, and the United States. All participants presented their scientific research to a diverse international audience. Through oral and poster presentations, the participants had to explain their research to colleagues outside of their subfields. This provided the students the chance to practice and improve their communication skills, which will serve them well in their future careers.  

A total of 70 students attended CAM 2019, with 15 from the United States, 38 from Canada, 14 from Mexico, and 3 from Cuba. All of the U.S. students were supported with funds from NSF. 

In summary, CAM 2019 introduced physics graduate students to an international scientific conference setting while providing the opportunity to: 

1. build connections with fellow students from other countries; 

2. develop professional skills for presenting research to an international audience and organizing an international meeting; 

3. gain a broader view of physics beyond their own physics research; 

4. facilitate discussions among students across physics disciplines; and 

5. establish new networks and relationships for future international scientific collaborations.
